content.title: Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm - Definition and Classification
content.summary: Permanent localized dilation of the thoracic aorta exceeding 50% of normal diameter, classified by anatomic location and extent of involvement.

definitions.definition: Permanent focal dilation of the thoracic aorta greater than 1.5 times the expected normal diameter (typically >4cm for descending, >4.5cm for ascending).
Aneurysm involving both the thoracic and abdominal aorta, classified by the Crawford classification based on extent of involvement.

key_concepts.explanation: TAAs are classified by location: Aortic Root (sinuses of Valsalva), Ascending Aorta, Aortic Arch, Descending Thoracic Aorta. Location determines surgical approach and risks.

Classification for thoracoabdominal aneurysms: Type I (distal to left subclavian to above renals), Type II (distal to left subclavian to infrarenal), Type III (mid-descending thoracic to infrarenal), Type IV (below diaphragm to infrarenal), Type V (below T6 to above renals).
Normal ascending aorta: 2.1cm/m² (men), 1.9cm/m² (women). Normal descending: 1.6cm/m². Aneurysm definition: >50% increase from expected normal or absolute threshold (commonly >4.0-4.5cm).
Degenerative (most common), Genetic (Marfan, Loeys-Dietz, Bicuspid valve), Post-dissection, Inflammatory (aortitis), Mycotic (infectious), Traumatic, Anastomotic.

evidence.finding: Rupture risk increases sharply above 6cm for ascending and 7cm for descending thoracic aneurysms
Surgical intervention recommended at 5.5cm for ascending (5.0cm for Marfan) and 6.0cm for descending TAA

clinical_pearls: TAAs are often incidental findings on imaging performed for other indications
Ascending aneurysms more often associated with genetic syndromes and bicuspid valve
Descending aneurysms more often degenerative, associated with smoking and hypertension
Growth rate of 0.1-0.3cm/year is typical; faster growth warrants earlier intervention
Type II TAAA has highest spinal cord ischemia risk due to extensive coverage of intercostals
learning_objectives: Define thoracic aortic aneurysm using size criteria
Apply the Crawford classification to thoracoabdominal aneurysms
Compare etiologies of ascending versus descending TAA
State size thresholds for surgical intervention
Identify patients requiring earlier intervention due to genetic syndromes
